head.title: Laura11 From a letter of Robert Burns to George Thomson, October 29, 1793. See James Currie's Works of Robert Burns, 4 vols. (Liverpool: M'Creery, 1800), IV: pp. 140-141. Subsequently published as "Song" in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 14, 1796), p. 4.

lg.l: Let me wander where I will
By shady wood or winding rill,
Where the sweetest may-born flow’rs
Paint the meadows and the bow’rs,
Where the linnet’s early song
Echoes sweet the groves among,
Or let me wander where I will,
Laura22 The name often associated with the laurel wreath; the subject of Petrarch’s love poetry. haunts my fancy still.
If at early dawn I chuse
To indulge the smiling muse,
If I court some cool retreat
To avoid the noon-day heat,
If beneath the moon’s pale ray
Through unfrequented wilds I stray,
Or let me wander where I will
Laura haunts my fancy still.
When at night the drowsy God33 Morpheus, god of dreams.

Waves his sleep compelling rod,44 Cf. “sleep-compelling rod,” in Dryden, Palemon and Arcite, line 550, but more closely, Turnbull, “Ode V. To Morpheus” in Poetical Essays (1788), epigraph. Cf. also “sleep that knits up the ravelled sleeve of care”: Shakespeare, Macbeth, II:ii. 36.
And to fancy’s wakeful eyes
Bids celestial visions rise,
Whilst with boundless joy I rove
Through the fairy land of love,
Or let me wander where I will,
O! Laura, haunt my fancy still.
